eventsFunctionsExtensions.description:
The camera follows an object according to:
- a frame rate independent catch-up speed to make the scrolling from smooth to strong
- a maximum speed to do linear following or slow down the camera when teleporting the object
- a follow-free zone to avoid scrolling on small movements
- an offset to see further in one direction
- an extra delay and catch-up speed to give an impression of speed (useful for dash)
- position forecasting and delay to simulate a cameraman response time

A platformer dedicated behavior allows to switch of settings when the character is in air or on the floor. This can be used to stabilize the camera when jumping.
eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: SmoothCamera
eventsFunctionsExtensions.previewIconUrl: https://resources.gdevelop-app.com/assets/Icons/Line Hero Pack/Master/SVG/Computers and Hardware/Computers and Hardware_camcoder_gopro_go_pro_camera.svg
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: Smoothly scroll to follow an object.

eventsBasedBehaviors.description: Smoothly scroll to follow an object.
eventsBasedBehaviors.name: SmoothCamera

events.comment: Update private properties through setters to check their values and initialize state.

Delaying and forecasting can be used at the same time.
Forecasting only use the positions that are older than the one used for delaying.
The behavior uses a position history that is split in 2 arrays:
- one for delaying the position (from TimeFromStart to TimeFromStart - CamearDelay)
- one for forecasting the position (from TimeFromStart - CamearDelay to TimeFromStart - CamearDelay - ForecastHistoryDuration

At each frame, the camera must catchup the target by a given ratio (speed)
cameraX(t) - targetX = (cameraX(t - 1) - targetX) * speed

The frame rate must not impact on the catch-up speed, we don't want a speed in ratio per frame but a speed ratio per second, like this:
cameraX(t) - targetX = (cameraX(t - 1s) - targetX) * speed

Ok, but we still need to process each frame, we can use a exponent for this:
cameraX(t) - targetX = (cameraX(t - timeDelta) - targetX) * speed^timeDelta
cameraX(t) = targetX + (cameraX(t - timeDelta) - targetX) * exp(timeDelta * ln(speed))

pow is probably more efficient than precalculated log if the speed is changed continuously but this might be rare enough.

eventsFunctions.sentence: Update delayed position and delayed history of _PARAM0_

events.comment: Add the previous position to have enough (2) positions to evaluate the extra delay for waiting mode.
Use the object center when no delay is asked.
Remove history entries that are too old to be useful for delaying and pass it to the history for forecasting.
Don't move the camera if there is not enough history.

Add the extra delay that could be needed to respect the speed limit in waiting mode.

speedRatio = min(speedMaxX / historySpeedX, speedMaxY / historySpeedY)
delay += min(0, timeDelta * (1 - speedRatio))
The time with delay is now between the first 2 indexes

events.comment:
Remove history entries that are too old to be useful.
Keep at least 2 positions because no forecast can be done with less positions.

eventsFunctions.description: Update forecasted position. This is called in doStepPreEvents.
eventsFunctions.name: UpdateForecastedPosition

events.comment:
Simple linear regression
y = A * x + B

A = Covariance / VarianceX
B = MeanY - A * MeanX

Note than we could use only one position every N positions to reduce the process time,
but if we really need efficient process JavaScript and circular queues are a must.

VarianceX = sum((X[i] - MeanX)²)
VarianceY = sum((Y[i] - MeanY)²)
Covariance = sum((X[i] - MeanX) * (Y[i] - MeanY))

y = A * x + B

A = Covariance / VarianceX
B = MeanY - A * MeanX
Axis permutation to avoid a ratio between 2 numbers near 0.
Permute back axis

eventsFunctions.description: Project history ends position to have the vector on the line from linear regression. This function is only called by UpdateForecastedPosition.
eventsFunctions.name: ProjectHistoryEnds
eventsFunctions.sentence: Project history oldest: _PARAM2_;_PARAM3_ and newest position: _PARAM4_;_PARAM5_ of _PARAM0_

events.comment:
Perpendicular line:
pA = -1/a; 
pB = -pA * x + y

Intersection:
/ ProjectedY = a * ProjectedX + b
\ ProjectedY = pA * ProjectedX + b

Solution that is cleaned out from indeterminism (like 0 / 0 or infinity / infinity):
ProjectedX= (x + (y - b) * a) / (a² + 1)
ProjectedY = y + (x * a - y + b) / (a² + 1)

eventsFunctions.description: Return the ratio between forecast time and the duration of the history. This function is only called by UpdateForecastedPosition.
eventsFunctions.name: ForecastTimeRatio

eventsFunctionsExtensions.author: @oscuridad6661, Tristan Rhodes (@VictrisGames)
eventsFunctionsExtensions.description:
How to use:
- Run the "Generate Dungeon Cave" or "Generate Dungeon with Rooms" action at the beginning of a scene.

Tips:
- Keep the amount of space used by room objects to less than ~25% of the total map.  If you add too many rooms, they will not be placed correctly and might collide with other rooms.
- Try using top-down controls combined with physics behavior (with no gravity) on the player and wall objects
- Use external layouts to place pre-designed rooms on randomly created room objects
- Use "Delete Unused Terrain" option to reduce resources used
- Use "RoomID(object)" expression to determine the starting and ending room
- Use "NeighborCount(object)" expression to find good places to place treasure.  A high amount of neighbors means that the tile is a nook or cranny.
- Use "IsRoomEntrance" condition to identify hallway objects that are adjacent to a room
eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: DungeonGenerator
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: Create a procedurally generated dungeon.  Includes two layouts: "rooms and hallways" and "dungeon cave".

eventsFunctions.description: Set the size of hallway objects to be placed on the path created by the pathfinding object.
eventsFunctions.name: AdjustHallwaySizes
eventsFunctions.sentence: Set the size of hallway objects _PARAM1_ to be placed on the path created by _PARAM2_ (Tile size: _PARAM4_ pixels, Hallway width: _PARAM5_ tiles)

events.comment: Set the default size of hallway object to the tilesize
Skip the first step in the path (so this function doesn't try to evaluate step 0)
Vertical move (previous frame)
Change in direction (this frame)
Horizontal move (previous frame)
Change in direction (this frame)

eventsFunctions.description: Fill world with terrain
eventsFunctions.name: FillWorld
eventsFunctions.sentence: Fill world with terrain (Tile size: _PARAM1_ pixels, Columns: _PARAM2_ tiles, Rows: _PARAM3_ tiles, Fill object: _PARAM4_)

events.name: Populate map with terrain objects everywhere

eventsFunctions.description: Generate a dungeon cave using a random walk algorithm.  When the walker touches an edge of the map, it is moved back to the center of map.
eventsFunctions.name: GenerateDungeonCave
eventsFunctions.sentence: Generate a dungeon cave that has _PARAM8_ percent floor objects (Tile size: _PARAM1_ pixels, Map width: _PARAM2_ tiles, Map height: _PARAM3_ tiles, Terrain object: _PARAM4_, Floor object: _PARAM5_, Wall object: _PARAM12_, Walker object: _PARAM7_, Walker width/height: _PARAM9_ tiles, Minimum border: _PARAM10_ tiles, Create objects on layer: _PARAM6_, Delete unused terrain: _PARAM11_, Calculate neighbors: _PARAM13_)

events.comment: Calculate the number of floor objects to be created.  Don't include border in calculation.  Multiply border by 2 because it needs to exist on both sides (top+bottom, left+right).
Initialize counters
Start with an empty map (array)
Initialize walker offsets (these are used to make the walker take up more than one tile)
Create (WalkerSize^2) quantity of objects (1x1=1, 2x2=4, 3x3=9, etc0

Create virtual walker objects. Walker objects are ONLY used to store variables and to perform ForEach() loops.  Position, size, and appearance DO NOT matter.  
TODO: These could be replaced by structure variables.
Calculate the starting position (in the 2D array) and save it so it can be used for restarts
Reset variables
Calculate chance to go in each direction based on the ratio of width to height
Generate a random number between 0 and 1
Move LEFT
Move RIGHT
Move UP
Move DOWN
If ANY Walker is outside map boundries, reset ALL of them to their starting positions
Check all Walkers if they are on top of terrain
Move back to starting position
If Walker is on Terrain, delete it
Track how many steps were taken
Loop through every tile in the map
Create terrain objects when array value is 0
Create floor objects when array value is 1
Add walls
Create walls where terrain touches floor
Delete walkers
Delete unused terrain (if desired)

parameters.longDescription: All objects are based on this size
parameters.name: TileSize

parameters.longDescription: Terrain object is used to fill the map that is not covered by floors, hallways, or walls.
parameters.name: TerrainObject

parameters.longDescription: Floor objects are created on every tile that a walker has travelled to.
parameters.name: FloorObject

parameters.longDescription: Use a random walk algorithm to turn terrain objects into floor objects
parameters.name: WalkerObject

parameters.longDescription: Percentage of map that will be convered by floor objects
parameters.name: FloorPercentage

parameters.longDescription: The number of tiles for each side of the square walker object.  For example, 2=2x2, 3=3x3, 4=4x4.
parameters.name: WalkerSize

parameters.longDescription: Can be used to provide a border of terrain around the map
parameters.name: MinBorder

parameters.longDescription: Wall objects are placed between floor and terrain objects.
parameters.name: WallObject

parameters.longDescription: May take a few seconds to calculate neighbors on a large map, so disable this if you are not using it.
parameters.name: CalculateNeighbors

eventsFunctions.description: Generate a dungeon by placing rooms in random locations and moving them if they collide with each other.  Rooms are connected with hallways.
eventsFunctions.fullName: Generate a dungeon with room and hallways
eventsFunctions.name: GenerateDungeonRooms
eventsFunctions.sentence: Generate a dungeon with rooms (Room Qty: _PARAM7_, Tile size: _PARAM1_ pixels, Map width: _PARAM2_ tiles, Map height: _PARAM3_ tiles, Terrain object: _PARAM4_, Room object: _PARAM5_, Wall object: _PARAM20_, Hallway object: _PARAM6_, Pathfinding object: _PARAM13_, Min room width: _PARAM9_ tiles, Max room width: _PARAM10_ tiles, Min room height: _PARAM11_ tiles, Max room height: _PARAM12_ tiles, Hallway width: _PARAM17_ tiles, Create objects on layer: _PARAM8_, Max separation attempts: _PARAM15_, Connect rooms in a loop: _PARAM16_, Additional paths: _PARAM18_, Delete unused terrain: _PARAM19_)

events.name: Populate map with terrain objects everywhere

events.comment: Create a new room in a random location on map
Change the room to a random size
Estimate starting distance between rooms
Set a default value for separation attempts
If rooms are close to each other, move them to a new random location
Move in a random direction the distance of a room
Move object back into the usable part of map
Create pathfinder object if one doesn't exist
Make sure pathfinding cell size matches tile size
Move the pathfinder object to a random starting room
Reset counter (used to assign RoomID to rooms)
Cycle through all rooms, always going to the nearest unvisited room
Assign path order if one does not exist
Set the destination of the pathfinder to the next room
Create a hallway object at every cell along the path to the destination
Adjust size of hallway objects
Move the pathfinder object to the room that was just connected with a hallway
If desired, connect a hallway from the last room to the first room
Set the destination of the pathfinder to the starting room
Create a hallway object at every cell along the path to the destination
Adjust size of hallway objects
Move the pathfinder object to the room that was just connected with a hallway
If desired, make additional random connections between rooms
Set the destination of the pathfinder to the next room (don't select the room that already has the pathfinder)
Create a hallway object at every cell along the path to the destination
Adjust size of hallway objects
Move the pathfinder object to the room that was just connected with a hallway

events.name: Remove terrain from rooms and hallways.

events.comment: Remove terrain from inside rooms and hallways.
Create walls where terrain touches hallways but not rooms
Create walls where terrain touches rooms but not hallways
Delete hallways that are at least partially inside of rooms
Set boolean flag for hallways that are doorways (adjacent to room but not touching)
Remove extra terrain, if needed
Cleanup pathfinder object

parameters.longDescription: All objects are based on this size
parameters.name: TileSize

parameters.longDescription: Used to fill the map that is not covered by floors, hallways, or walls.
parameters.name: TerrainObject

parameters.longDescription: Rooms are placed in random locations and will try to not overlap with other rooms.
parameters.name: RoomObject

parameters.longDescription: Used to connect room objects.  They follow the path made by the pathfinder object.

parameters.longDescription: Rooms should take less than ~25% of map to ensure non-overlapping rooms.  If there are too many rooms, they may end up overlapping each other.
parameters.name: RoomQty

parameters.longDescription: Used to identify where hallways are placed between rooms
parameters.name: PathfinderObject

parameters.longDescription: Number of attempts to separate overalapping rooms.  When this number is reached, rooms are left in current position. (Default: 10,000)
parameters.name: MaxSeparationAttempts

eventsFunctionsExtensions.description:
Enables users to click and drag on objects to move them.  The object will retain velocity when the click is released, which can allow users to fling objects across the screen.

Note:
- The standard "draggable" behavior will not work on objects that have the physics behavior. This extension should be used instead.
- This extension will only work on objects that have the physics behavior.

eventsFunctionsExtensions.author: Arthur Pacaud (arthuro555)
eventsFunctionsExtensions.description:
This extension allows to use WebSocket based networking. 
You can use it to interact with a WebSocket based API, or a server for your multiplayer game.

Features:
 - Connection and disconnection from a server
 - Receiving strings from the server
 - Sending strings to the server
 - Error handling
 - Handling more than 1 event per frame

Doesn't contain:
 - Sending or receiving binary data
 - A WebSocket server
eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: WebSocketClient
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: A WebSocket client for fast client-server networking.

eventsFunctions.description: Triggers if the client is currently connecting to the WebSocket server.
eventsFunctions.name: IsConnecting

eventsFunctions.name: IsConnected

eventsFunctions.name: IsClosed

eventsFunctions.name: Disconnect

eventsFunctions.name: Data

eventsFunctionsExtensions.description:
Games with pixel art usually use pixels bigger than actual pixels of the screen. This can lead to big pixels partially overlapping each other which doesn't look good.

This extension allows to seamlessly keep big pixels aligned when the object is stopped and still beneficiate from the high resolution of the screen to have smooth movements.
eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: PixelPerfectMovement
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: Pixel perfect platformer and top-down movements.

eventsBasedBehaviors.description: Seamlessly align big pixels using a top-down movement.
eventsBasedBehaviors.name: PixelPerfectTopDownMovement

events.comment: Find how far to go to reach a pixel.

parameters: Object.Behavior::PropertyOffsetX() + Object.Behavior::PropertyPixelSize() * ceil((Object.X() + PixelPerfectMovement::BrakingDistance(Object.TopDownMovement::XVelocity(), Object.TopDownMovement::Deceleration()) - Object.Behavior::PropertyOffsetX()) / Object.Behavior::PropertyPixelSize())

Object.Behavior::PropertyOffsetX() + Object.Behavior::PropertyPixelSize() * floor((Object.X() - PixelPerfectMovement::BrakingDistance(Object.TopDownMovement::XVelocity(), Object.TopDownMovement::Deceleration()) - Object.Behavior::PropertyOffsetX()) / Object.Behavior::PropertyPixelSize())

events.comment: Move to the target as the movement behavior would do.
Find how far to go to reach a pixel.

parameters: Object.Behavior::PropertyOffsetY() + Object.Behavior::PropertyPixelSize() * ceil((Object.Y() + PixelPerfectMovement::BrakingDistance(Object.TopDownMovement::YVelocity(), Object.TopDownMovement::Deceleration()) - Object.Behavior::PropertyOffsetY()) / Object.Behavior::PropertyPixelSize())

Object.Behavior::PropertyOffsetY() + Object.Behavior::PropertyPixelSize() * floor((Object.Y() - PixelPerfectMovement::BrakingDistance(Object.TopDownMovement::YVelocity(), Object.TopDownMovement::Deceleration()) - Object.Behavior::PropertyOffsetY()) / Object.Behavior::PropertyPixelSize())

events.comment: Move to the target as the movement behavior would do.

The "separate" action can leave the object position with rounding errors.
The snaping is applied doStepPostEvent rather than at the beginning of doPreEvent because it must be done before the top-down movement is applied.

eventsFunctions.description: Snap on the grid horizontally to remove rounding errors that could happen with the separate action.
eventsFunctions.name: SnapRoundingErrorX
eventsFunctions.sentence: Snap _PARAM0_ on the grid horizontally if there is any rounding error

eventsFunctions.description: Snap on the grid vertically to remove rounding errors that could happen with the separate action.
eventsFunctions.name: SnapRoundingErrorY
eventsFunctions.sentence: Snap _PARAM0_ on the grid vertically if there is any rounding error

eventsBasedBehaviors.description: Seamlessly align big pixels using a platformer character movement.
eventsBasedBehaviors.name: PixelPerfectPlatformerCharacter

events.comment: Find how far to go to reach a pixel.
Move to the target as the movement behavior would do.
Find how far to go to reach a pixel.
Move to the target as the movement behavior would do.

eventsFunctionsExtensions.author: Tristan Rhodes (https://victrisgames.itch.io/)
eventsFunctionsExtensions.description:
The scale of the object decreases the closer it is to the horizon, giving the illusion that the object is travelling away from the viewer.

Properties:
- Horizon Y position (Default: 0)
- Max scale of the object when it is at the bottom of the screen (Default: 1)
- Y exponent can be used to control the rate of change  (Default: 2)

Tips:
- If you want speed to look constant, be sure to reduce the object's speed based on scale or Y value.  If you don't do this, the object will appear to be moving faster when it is near the top of the screen.  This matches how objects appear in the real world.
- This extension works well with the Y-sort extension, which changes Z order based on Y position.
eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: DepthEffect
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: Change scale based on Y position to simulate depth of field.

eventsBasedBehaviors.description: The scale of the object decreases the closer it is to the horizon, giving the illusion that the object is travelling away from the viewer.
eventsBasedBehaviors.name: DepthEffect_Text

events.comment:
Determine the percent the object is from the horizon to the bottom of the screen.  
Make sure this value never goes below 0 (otherwise it can become a positive value when squared).

Change the scale of the object based on it's relative position from horizon and bottom of screen.
Make sure the exponent never goes below 1.

eventsFunctions.description: Percent away from horizon.  This is 0 at the horizon, and 1 at the bottom of the screen.
eventsFunctions.name: PercentAwayFromHorizon

eventsFunctions.description: Exponential rate of change in scale based on the Y position.

eventsFunctions.description: Set Y position of horizon, where objects are infinitely small (Default: 0).

eventsFunctionsExtensions.description:
Can be used to create enemies, NPCs, environmental objects, etc.

How to use:
- Add this behavior to an object
- Place spawners on the scene 
- Run the "Spawn objects" action on every frame
- Control spawning by adjusting behavior properties

Properties:
Spawn period:  Number of seconds before spawning another object.
Max quantity:  Each spawner will try to maintain this number of spawned objects
Offset X/Y:  Use to adjust where the object are spawned, relative to the origin of the spawner

Tips:
- Use "Object was just spawned" condition to trigger visual and sound effects (if desired)
- Set max quantity to "0" to never stop spawning objects
- Spawned objects are automatically linked to the spawner
- Note:  If max quantity has been reached and an instance is deleted, the spawner will wait the duration of spawn period before creating another instance.
eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: ObjectSpawner

eventsFunctions.description: Spawn (create) objects periodically.
eventsFunctions.name: SpawnObject
eventsFunctions.sentence: Periodically spawn (create) a _PARAM2_ located at spawner _PARAM0_

events.comment: Always spawn objects if quantity is set to "0"
Check if max number of instances per spawner has been reached
This is used so that objects are not immediately spawned after deleting an instance after max instances had been reached
Check if max number of instances per spawner has been reached
Reset spawn detection
Spawn an object when conditions are met
Note: Spawned objects are linked to the spawner to check their number per spawner

eventsFunctionsExtensions.author: VegeTato
eventsFunctionsExtensions.description:
Reflection extension is useful when it comes to reflecting objects, like a player walking on water/glass/beach.
An action let you set the reflection for specific objects with a lot of options:

- The reflection opacity
- Reflective surface object
- Z order of the reflection
- An option to turn ON/OFF to delete the reflection when it touch the original object
- Touch distance to delete the reflection
- Layer to create the reflection on
eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: Reflection
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: Add a reflection to a selected object.

eventsFunctions.description: Reflect your object.
eventsFunctions.name: Reflect
eventsFunctions.sentence: Create reflection _PARAM1_ of _PARAM2_ at distance _PARAM3_ and _PARAM4_ opacity on the floor _PARAM5_ at Zorder _PARAM6_ and layer _PARAM7_ delete on touch _PARAM8_ touch distance _PARAM9_

parameters.longDescription: A different object than the original object
parameters.name: ReflectionObject

parameters.longDescription: Distance in pixel, default: 0px
parameters.name: Distance

parameters.longDescription: Between 0 transparent to 255 opaque
parameters.name: Opacity

parameters.description: Layer to create the reflection (Base layer by default)
parameters.name: Layer

parameters.description: Delete reflection when it collides with the original object (default: no)
parameters.name: Remove

parameters.longDescription: Distance between the reflection and the original object before deleting the reflection (0 by default for immediate delete when touch)
parameters.name: DeleteDistance

eventsFunctionsExtensions.author: Tristan Rhodes (tristan@victrisgames.com)
eventsFunctionsExtensions.description:
This extension can be used to create multiple copies of an object in a wide variety of arrangements, including:
- horizontal row(s)
- vertical column(s)
- a solid rectangle or square
- an evenly spaced grid
- a grid with different spacing between rows and columns

After the objects are created, you can reference their object variables to manage the objects:

* `RowID`:  what horizontal row does this object reside in,
* `ColumnID`:  what vertical column does this object reside in,
* `CreationID`:  starting top-left, and proceeding from left to right, what is the number of the created object,
* `BatchID`:  optional identifier assigned to all objects created

Watch this [tutorial video](https://youtu.be/rlGSlNSRR9w) to see examples of how to use this extension.
eventsFunctionsExtensions.fullName: Create multiple copies of an object
eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: CreateMultipleCopiesOfObject
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: Select the object, choose the number of rows and columns, the spacing between rows and columns, the top left starting point, the layer to create the objects on, and the z-order of the objects.

eventsFunctions.description:
Create multiple copies of an object.
Select the object, choose the number of rows and columns, the spacing between rows and columns, the top left starting point, the layer to create the objects on, and the z-order of the objects.
eventsFunctions.fullName: Create multiple copies of an object
eventsFunctions.name: CreateMultipleCopiesOfObject
eventsFunctions.sentence: Create _PARAM2_ rows and _PARAM3_ columns of _PARAM1_ objects, with top-left starting position _PARAM4_;_PARAM5_, with _PARAM6_px between rows and _PARAM7_px between columns. Create objects on _PARAM9_ with a Z-value of _PARAM10_. Assign all objects the BatchID of _PARAM8_

events.comment: Temp object is created to record its width and height (which is needed to calculate spacing).
Temp variables to track progress in drawing the grid
Starting at top left, create objects in grid.
If the current row is complete, move to the next row.
If the last row is complete, stop creating new objects.

parameters.description: (Optional) Identifier assigned to all objects created in this batch
parameters.name: BatchID

eventsFunctionsExtensions.author: @4ian, Tristan Rhodes (https://victrisgames.itch.io/)
eventsFunctionsExtensions.description:
Allow an object to move in a rectangular pattern.
By default, movement will slow down when going around corners, but this can be changed to always use a constant speed.

Example uses:
- Moveable platforms
- Enemy movement patterns

Properties:
- Center of movement, X position
- Center of movement, Y position
- Horizontal distance
- Vertical distance
- Horizontal speed
- Vertical speed
- Use constant speed (object will not slow down at corners)
- Use counter-clockwise direction

Tips:
- Set the CenterX and CenterY values to move the object
- For horizontal movement only, set vertical distance to 0
- For vertical movement only, set horizontal distance to 0
- Use conditions to apply logic based on the direction the object is moving.  For example, setting the animation.
eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: RectangularMovement
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: Allow an object to move in a rectangular pattern.

eventsBasedBehaviors.description: Allow an object to move in a rectangular pattern.
